title: Erdős Problem #1130: Lagrange Basis Function Sums
description: For nodes in [-1,1], is the minimum over subintervals of the max Lebesgue function at most O(log n)? PROVED: Υ ≤ (2/π) log n + O(1). De Boor–Pinkus characterized the optimal nodes.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about Lagrange interpolation in 1947. The Lebesgue function Λ(x) = Σ|l_k(x)| measures how much interpolation amplifies errors. Erdős asked whether the functional Υ, the minimum over subintervals of the max Lebesgue function, grows at most logarithmically.
overview.problemStatement: For points x₁,...,xₙ ∈ [-1,1], is Υ(x₁,...,xₙ) = min_i max_{x∈[xᵢ,xᵢ₊₁]} Σ|l_k(x)| at most O(log n)?
overview.proofStrategy: Defines Lagrange basis polynomials, the Lebesgue function, and the Υ functional. States Erdős's initial √n bound, the optimal (2/π)log n + O(1) bound, and the de Boor–Pinkus characterization of maximizing nodes.
keyInsights: The Lebesgue function measures the worst-case amplification of interpolation errors
Erdős first proved Υ < √n, far from the conjectured log n
The sharp bound (2/π) log n + O(1) matches the classical Lebesgue constant up to the Υ minimization
De Boor–Pinkus showed optimal nodes equalize the Lebesgue function across subintervals

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 1130 is PROVED: the Υ functional grows as (2/π) log n + O(1). De Boor and Pinkus characterized the nodes maximizing Υ as those equalizing the Lebesgue function across all subintervals.
conclusion.implications: The result has implications for numerical analysis, polynomial approximation theory, and the choice of interpolation nodes.
openQuestions: What is the exact constant in the O(1) term?
How does the optimal node distribution relate to Chebyshev points asymptotically?
Are there analogues for multivariate interpolation?
